entry.title: How childhood exercise could maintain and promote cognitive function in later life
entry.summary: People who are physically active during childhood have higher cognitive functions in later life. Participants who exercised when they were children did better on cognitive tests regardless of their current age. However, no such relationship was found between task performance and post-childhood exercise -- suggesting that exercise during childhood is particularly important for brain development and long-term cognitive health.

entry.title: Tug-of-war receptors for sour taste in fruit flies sheds light on human taste biology
entry.summary: Sour taste does not have the nearly universal appeal that sweet taste does. Slightly sour foods or drinks such as yogurt and lemon juice are yummy to many, but such highly sour foods as spoiled milk are yucky, even dangerous. Like humans, many other animals, including insects, prefer slightly acidic over very acidic foods.

entry.title: Focus on emotions is key to improving heart health in people living with obesity
entry.summary: People living with obesity who attended a non-judgemental and personalized lifestyle modification program improved their cardiovascular and mental health during just 10 weeks, according to a new study. Participants lost weight and achieved benefits in anxiety and depression and physical measurements including blood pressure.

entry.title: Focus on emotions is key to improving heart health in people living with obesity
entry.summary: People living with obesity who attended a non-judgemental and personalized lifestyle modification program improved their cardiovascular and mental health during just 10 weeks, according to a new study. Participants lost weight and achieved benefits in anxiety and depression and physical measurements including blood pressure.

entry.title: Stress during pandemic linked to poor sleep
entry.summary: A study found that stress, anxiety and depression during the first few weeks of the pandemic were associated with less and lower quality sleep. In a survey of more than 900 twins, about half of the respondents reported no change in sleep patterns, but 32.9 percent reported decreased sleep. Another 29.8 percent reported sleeping more. The researchers found that any change in sleep was connected to self-reported mental health issues, though more strongly associated with decreased sleep.

entry.title: Stress during pandemic linked to poor sleep
entry.summary: A study found that stress, anxiety and depression during the first few weeks of the pandemic were associated with less and lower quality sleep. In a survey of more than 900 twins, about half of the respondents reported no change in sleep patterns, but 32.9 percent reported decreased sleep. Another 29.8 percent reported sleeping more. The researchers found that any change in sleep was connected to self-reported mental health issues, though more strongly associated with decreased sleep.

entry.title: Having a strong life purpose eases loneliness of COVID-19 isolation, study finds
entry.summary: Why can some people weather the stress of social isolation better than others, and what implications does this have for their health? New research found that people who felt a strong sense of purpose in life were less lonely during the COVID-19 pandemic.

entry.title: Dependabot now schedules version updates uniformly
entry.summary: Dependabot now schedules version updates uniformly

entry.title: New tools to discover and resolve pull request conversations now generally available
entry.summary: New tools to discover and resolve pull request conversations now generally available

entry.title: Human infant brains, bodies are active during new sleep stage
entry.summary: A team has found that babies twitch during a sleep stage called quiet sleep, not just during REM sleep. The results may show there's more communication between snoozing infants' brains and motor systems than previously known.

entry.title: Link found between gut microbes and stroke
entry.summary: New findings show that the gut microbiome impacts stroke severity and functional impairment following stroke. The results lay the groundwork for potential new interventions to help treat or prevent stroke.

entry.title: New study finds fresh evidence for our inevitable death
entry.summary: Philosophers, artists and scientists - and probably all the rest of us - have long obsessed over the key to human immortality. We all, no matter our income, culture or religion are bound to die. Even if we escape mortal diseases or accidents, we all face a deadly biological deterioration. While the debate of human longevity has divided the scientific community for centuries, a new study finds fresh evidence for our inevitable death.

entry.title: Compounds derived from hops show promise as treatment for common liver disease
entry.summary: Research suggests a pair of compounds originating from hops can help thwart a dangerous buildup of fat in the liver known as hepatic steatosis.

entry.title: New treatment stops progression of Alzheimer's disease in monkey brains
entry.summary: A new therapy prompts immune defense cells to swallow misshapen proteins, amyloid beta plaques and tau tangles, whose buildup is known to kill nearby brain cells as part of Alzheimer's disease, a new study shows.

entry.title: Brain cell membranes' lipids may play big role in Alzheimer's progression
entry.summary: Links between lipid imbalance and disease have been established, in which lipid changes increase the formation of amyloid plaques, a hallmark of Alzheimer's disease. This imbalance inspired researchers to explore the role of lipids comprising the cellular membranes of brain cells. In Biointerphases, the researchers report on the significant role lipids may play in regulating C99, a protein within the amyloid pathway, and disease progression.

entry.title: Adults who skip morning meal likely to miss out on nutrients
entry.summary: Adults who skip breakfast are likely to miss out on key nutrients that are most abundant in the foods that make up morning meals, a new study suggests.

entry.title: Air pollution exposure during pregnancy may boost babies' obesity risk
entry.summary: New research shows pregnant women exposed to higher levels of air pollution have babies who grow unusually fast in the first months after birth, putting on excess fat that may put them at risk of obesity and related diseases later in life.

entry.title: Air pollution exposure during pregnancy may boost babies' obesity risk
entry.summary: New research shows pregnant women exposed to higher levels of air pollution have babies who grow unusually fast in the first months after birth, putting on excess fat that may put them at risk of obesity and related diseases later in life.

entry.title: Obesity and hypertension: Researchers discover novel mechanisms
entry.summary: Researchers have succeeded for the first time in demonstrating the role of hypothalamic astrocytes in obesity-related hypertension. In addition, they showed that the hormone leptin is involved in the increase of blood vessels in the hypothalamus of obese mice, contributing of hypertension.

entry.title: Main gland in hormonal system ages due to process that can potentially be slowed down
entry.summary: Stem cell biologist have discovered that the pituitary gland in mice ages as the result of an age-related form of chronic inflammation. It may be possible to slow down this process or even partially repair it.

entry.title: Healthy fat impacted by change in diet and circadian clock
entry.summary: Changing your eating habits or altering your circadian clock can impact healthy fat tissue throughout your lifespan, according to a preclinical study.

entry.title: New health benefits of red seaweeds unveiled
entry.summary: Red seaweeds have been prevalent in the diets of Asian communities for thousands of years. Researchers have now shown how these algae confer health benefits.

entry.title: Persistence pays off in the human gut microbiome
entry.summary: The human gut microbiome is a complex community of trillions of microbes that are constantly interacting with each other and our bodies. It supports our wellbeing, immune system and mental health -- but how is it sustained?

entry.title: The evolution of good taste
entry.summary: Does evolution explain why we can't resist a salty chip? Researchers found that differences between the elemental composition of foods and the elemental needs of animals can explain the development of pleasing tastes like salty, umami and sweet.

entry.title: Potential new treatment target for Alzheimer's disease
entry.summary: A new study not only sheds light on how the APOE4 gene may cause some of the pathologies associated with Alzheimer's disease, but also suggests a new treatment target that might help people who carry the APOE4 gene in early and late stages of the disease. Researchers found that APOE4 is associated with the activation of an inflammatory protein that causes a breakdown in the blood-brain barrier which protects the brain.

entry.title: A new model of Alzheimer's progression
entry.summary: Scientists explore how protein and signaling pathways change in patients with Alzheimer's disease. Their work creates a new model of disease progression, taking advantage of the heterogeneity that is inherent to human studies.

entry.title: Plant-based diet protects from hypertension, preeclampsia
entry.summary: A plant-based diet appears to afford significant protection to rats bred to become hypertensive on a high-salt diet, scientists report. When the rats become pregnant, the whole grain diet also protects the mothers and their offspring from deadly preeclampsia.

entry.title: How gender norms and job loss affect relationship status
entry.summary: Research shows that, in cultures that value men as breadwinners, their unemployment can affect the long-term success of a romantic relationship.

entry.title: Young adults who lost and then restored heart health had lower risk of heart attack, stroke
entry.summary: A long-term analysis of young adults in Korea found that those with poor heart health had higher rates of cardiovascular disease at a younger age. Young adults with poor cardiovascular health who improved their cardiovascular health over time reduced their chances of heart attack, stroke or heart failure later in life. Those who maintained good cardiovascular health from a young age had the lowest risk of premature cardiovascular disease.

entry.title: New super-resolution technique allows for more detailed brain imaging
entry.summary: A new imaging technique has the potential to detect neurological disorders -- such as Alzheimer's disease -- at their earliest stages, enabling physicians to diagnose and treat patients more quickly. Termed super-resolution, the imaging methodology combines position emission tomography (PET) with an external motion tracking device to create highly detailed images of the brain.

entry.title: Vitamin D deficiency may increase risk for addiction to opioids and ultraviolet rays
entry.summary: Lab animals deficient in vitamin D crave and become dependent on opioids, which is curbed when normal levels of the vitamin are restored. Human health records indicate that people with low vitamin D are more likely to use and misuse opioids. Study results suggest a potential role for vitamin D supplementation in fighting opioid addiction.

entry.title: You can now buy this theme
entry.summary: I recently released the theme for macwright.com for sale on Ko-fi. Today I’m adding the /photos section to that theme (something I’ve written about before), and giving a little background information. This site’s brutalist design is the result of about a decade of refinement and tweaking. For specific goals - minimalism, optimization, adaptability, clarity - I think it has achieved a certain balance. I get an email about which theme I’m using every month or two. The answer is, well, this one. I started from a blank HTML page a decade ago, and have tried to make it better ever since. Better in a few ways: Clean bill of health from Google Lighthouse: 100 in performance, accessibility, and SEO. Real accessibility, based on real feedback from folks with reduced vision. Pages are tiny and excep…

entry.title: Study identifies how COVID-19 linked to Alzheimer's disease-like cognitive impairment
entry.summary: A new study has identified mechanisms by which COVID-19 can lead to Alzheimer's disease-like dementia. The findings indicate an overlap between COVID-19 and brain changes common in Alzheimer's, and may help inform risk management and therapeutic strategies for COVID-19-associated cognitive impairment.

entry.title: Forget me not: Novel target shows promise in treating Alzheimer's and related dementias
entry.summary: Researchers have identified a previously unknown early driver of Alzheimer's disease (AD) and vascular dementia (VaD). They report high levels of cis P-tau, a pathogenic protein, in human AD and VaD brains as well as preclinical disease models. Treatment with an antibody to the toxic protein prevented disease progression and reversed disease symptoms and restored cognitive function in older mice.

entry.title: Music listening near bedtime disruptive to sleep
entry.summary: Most people listen to music throughout their day and often near bedtime to wind down. But can that actually cause your sleep to suffer? When a sleep researcher realized he was waking in the middle of the night with a song stuck in his head, he saw an opportunity to study how music -- and particularly stuck songs -- might affect sleep patterns.

entry.title: 'Roadmaps' of the brain reveal regions vulnerable to Alzheimer's disease
entry.summary: Much like a supply truck crossing the countryside, the misfolded proteins that damage neurons in Alzheimer's disease travel the 'roads' of the brain, sometimes stopping and sometimes re-routing to avoid roadblocks.

entry.title: Memory biomarkers confirm aerobic exercise helps cognitive function in older adults
entry.summary: Until now, systemic biomarkers to measure exercise effects on brain function and that link to relevant metabolic responses were lacking. A study shows a memory biomarker, myokine Cathepsin B (CTSB), increased in older adults following a 26-week structured aerobic exercise training. The positive association between CTSB and cognition, and the substantial modulation of lipid metabolites implicated in dementia, support the beneficial effects of exercise training on brain function and brain health in asymptomatic individuals at risk for Alzheimer's.

entry.title: Memory biomarkers confirm aerobic exercise helps cognitive function in older adults
entry.summary: Until now, systemic biomarkers to measure exercise effects on brain function and that link to relevant metabolic responses were lacking. A study shows a memory biomarker, myokine Cathepsin B (CTSB), increased in older adults following a 26-week structured aerobic exercise training. The positive association between CTSB and cognition, and the substantial modulation of lipid metabolites implicated in dementia, support the beneficial effects of exercise training on brain function and brain health in asymptomatic individuals at risk for Alzheimer's.

entry.title: Dependabot now supports Terraform 1.0
entry.summary: Dependabot now supports Terraform 1.0

entry.title: Largescale brain epigenetics study provides new insights into dementia
entry.summary: The team looked in different regions of the brain, which are affected in Alzheimer's disease before looking for common changes across these cortical regions. They identified 220 sites in the genome, including 84 new genes, which showed different levels of DNA methylation in the cortex in individuals with more severe Alzheimer's disease, which weren't seen in the cerebellum.

entry.title: Dependabot updated `pip`, `pip-tools`, and `pipenv` support
entry.summary: Dependabot updated `pip`, `pip-tools`, and `pipenv` support

entry.title: Having trouble falling asleep predicts cognitive impairment in later life
entry.summary: A study of nearly 2,500 adults found that having trouble falling asleep, as compared to other patterns of insomnia, was the main insomnia symptom that predicted cognitive impairment 14 years later.

entry.title: Having trouble falling asleep predicts cognitive impairment in later life
entry.summary: A study of nearly 2,500 adults found that having trouble falling asleep, as compared to other patterns of insomnia, was the main insomnia symptom that predicted cognitive impairment 14 years later.

entry.title: Having trouble falling asleep predicts cognitive impairment in later life
entry.summary: A study of nearly 2,500 adults found that having trouble falling asleep, as compared to other patterns of insomnia, was the main insomnia symptom that predicted cognitive impairment 14 years later.

entry.title: Persistent insomnia symptoms since childhood associated with mood, anxiety disorders
entry.summary: A 15-year longitudinal study shows that childhood insomnia symptoms that persist into adulthood are strong determinants of mood and anxiety disorders in young adults.

entry.title: Persistent insomnia symptoms since childhood associated with mood, anxiety disorders
entry.summary: A 15-year longitudinal study shows that childhood insomnia symptoms that persist into adulthood are strong determinants of mood and anxiety disorders in young adults.

entry.title: Women's mental health has higher association with dietary factors
entry.summary: Women's mental health likely has a higher association with dietary factors than men's, according to new research.

entry.title: Women's mental health has higher association with dietary factors
entry.summary: Women's mental health likely has a higher association with dietary factors than men's, according to new research.

entry.title: Open source API portal now generally availabile
entry.summary: You can create and publish a customized site with API documentation, automatically generated from OpenAPI files.

entry.title: Drinking alcohol is linked to reduced chances of pregnancy
entry.summary: A study of the associations between drinking alcohol and the chances of becoming pregnant suggests that women who want to conceive should avoid heavy drinking. In the second half of menstrual cycle even moderate drinking is linked to reduced chances of pregnancy.

entry.title: Study finds novel evidence that dreams reflect multiple memories, anticipate future events
entry.summary: Dreams result from a process that often combines fragments of multiple life experiences and anticipates future events, according to novel evidence from a new study.

entry.title: Study finds novel evidence that dreams reflect multiple memories, anticipate future events
entry.summary: Dreams result from a process that often combines fragments of multiple life experiences and anticipates future events, according to novel evidence from a new study.

entry.title: Discovery of circadian rhythm gene in mice could lead to breakthroughs
entry.summary: Scientists have identified a novel gene, Per2AS, that controls the sleep/wake cycle in mice. Per2AS appears to be a new type of gene, known as a non-coding gene. Unlike most other genes, Per2AS is not translated from RNA into a subsequent protein, thus making its function unclear until now.

entry.title: Security alert notifications are now opt-in
entry.summary: Security alert notifications are now opt-in

entry.title: New issue and pull request state icons
entry.summary: New issue and pull request state icons

entry.title: Brownout Notice: API Authentication via Query Parameters, and the OAuth Applications API for 24 hours
entry.summary: Brownout Notice: API Authentication via Query Parameters, and the OAuth Applications API for 24 hours

entry.title: RubyGems, Adobe and OpenAI are now GitHub secret scanning integrators
entry.summary: RubyGems, Adobe and OpenAI are now GitHub secret scanning integrators

entry.title: Artificial intelligence enhances efficacy of sleep disorder treatments
entry.summary: An algorithm based on 20,000 nights of sleep that can improve the diagnosis, treatment and our overall understanding of sleep disorders has been developed.

entry.title: Preclinical study suggests new approach to reduce COVID-19 death among the elderly
entry.summary: New research reveals a possible new approach to preventing death and severe disease in elderly people infected with SARS-CoV-2. Researchers demonstrated in a preclinical study that senolytic drugs significantly reduced mortality upon infection from a beta-coronavirus closely related to SARS-CoV-2 in older mice.

entry.title: Weak brain waves may warn of age-related neurodegenerative disease
entry.summary: Weakened electrical signals in the brain may be an early warning sign of age-related neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's disease.

entry.title: Men with sensory loss are more likely to be obese
entry.summary: Men who suffer sensory loss, particularly hearing loss, are more likely to be physically inactive and obese than women, according to a new study.

entry.title: Exercise likely to be best treatment for depression in coronary heart disease
entry.summary: A study indicates that exercise is probably the most effective short-term treatment for depression in people with coronary heart disease, when compared to antidepressants and psychotherapy or more complex care.

entry.title: People who have trouble sleeping are at a higher risk of dying early - especially diabetics
entry.summary: People with sleep problems are at an increased risk of dying young, finds a new study.

entry.title: People who have trouble sleeping are at a higher risk of dying early - especially diabetics
entry.summary: People with sleep problems are at an increased risk of dying young, finds a new study.

entry.title: Sugar overload may be a recipe for long-term problems
entry.summary: Children who consume too much sugar could be at greater risk of becoming obese, hyperactive, and cognitively impaired, as adults, according to the results of a new study.

entry.title: Sorting out old password hashes
entry.summary: Starting with libxcrypt 4.4.21, weak password hashes (such as MD5 and SHA1) are no longer accepted for new passwords. Users that still have their passwords stored with a weak hash will be asked to update their password on their next login. If the login just fails (for example from display manager) switch to a virtual terminal (Ctrl-Alt-F2) and log in there once.

entry.title: Defying body clock linked to depression and lower wellbeing
entry.summary: People whose sleep pattern goes against their natural body clock are more likely to have depression and lower levels of wellbeing, according to a large-scale new study.

entry.title: Defying body clock linked to depression and lower wellbeing
entry.summary: People whose sleep pattern goes against their natural body clock are more likely to have depression and lower levels of wellbeing, according to a large-scale new study.

entry.title: Installation access token creation requests now respect IP allow list settings
entry.summary: Installation access token creation requests now respect IP allow list settings

entry.title: New drug to halt dementia after multiple head injuries
entry.summary: An international study has identified a new drug to stop athletes developing dementia after sustaining repeated head injuries in their career.

entry.title: Popularity runs in families
entry.summary: To investigate the role genes play in the evolution of social structure, researchers created an experiment they likened to the 1998 film 'The Truman Show.' Genetically identical versions of 20 fruit flies were placed in 98 controlled enclosures, and video cameras recorded their interactions. The study revealed the same clones occupied the same social positions in each enclosure, regardless of living conditions, providing evidence that popularity is heritable.

entry.title: Applying mathematics takes 'friendship paradox' beyond averages
entry.summary: In network science, the famous 'friendship paradox' describes why your friends are (on average) more popular, richer, and more attractive than you are. But a slightly more nuanced picture emerges when we apply mathematics to real-world data.

entry.title: Researchers identify a molecule critical to functional brain rejuvenation
entry.summary: A new study has identified a molecule called ten-eleven-translocation 1 (TET1) as a necessary component in the repair of myelin, which protects nerves and facilitates accurate transmission of electrical signals. The discovery could have important implications in treating neurodegenerative diseases and for molecular rejuvenation of aging brains in healthy individuals.

entry.title: Simple blood test can accurately reveal underlying neurodegeneration
entry.summary: A new study of over 3000 people, has shown for the first time that a single biomarker can accurately indicate the presence of underlying neurodegeneration in people with cognitive issues.

entry.title: Food scientists aim to make plant-based protein tastier and healthier
entry.summary: As meat-eating continues to increase around the world, food scientists are focusing on ways to create healthier, better-tasting and more sustainable plant-based protein products that mimic meat, fish, milk, cheese and eggs.

entry.title: Secret scanning now supports user defined patterns on private repositories
entry.summary: Secret scanning now supports user defined patterns on private repositories

entry.title: GitHub Enterprise Server 3.1 is now generally available
entry.summary: GitHub Enterprise Server 3.1 is now generally available

entry.title: Is elevated level of lung protein an early predictor for COPD?
entry.summary: Researcher had previously discovered that the total mucin concentrations in the lungs are associated with COPD disease progression and could be used as diagnostic markers of chronic bronchitis, a hallmark condition for patients with COPD. They now report that one of these mucins, MUC5AC, is more closely and reliably associated with the development of COPD than is its brother, MUC5B.

entry.title: Studies reveal skull as unexpected source of brain immunity
entry.summary: Researchers have discovered that the immune cells that protect the brain and spinal cord come primarily from the skull. The finding opens up the possibility of developing therapies to target such cells as a way to prevent or treat brain conditions.

entry.title: Public preview: Identity-based connections in Azure Functions with latest Azure SDK triggers and bindings
entry.summary: Azure functions can now connect using an identity instead of a secret.

entry.title: Secondary infections inflame the brain, worsening cognition in Alzheimer's disease
entry.summary: New research into Alzheimer's disease (AD) suggests that secondary infections and new inflammatory events amplify the brain's immune response and affect memory in mice and in humans -- even when these secondary events occur outside the brain.

entry.title: Control which code scanning alerts cause a pull request check to fail
entry.summary: Control which code scanning alerts cause a pull request check to fail

entry.title: Declining fish biodiversity poses risks for human nutrition
entry.summary: All fish are not created equal, at least when it comes to nutritional benefits. This truth has important implications for how declining fish biodiversity can affect human nutrition, according to a computer modeling study.

entry.title: Packages: ghcr.io maintenance mode on 2021-06-05
entry.summary: Packages: ghcr.io maintenance mode on 2021-06-05

entry.title: Kids who sleep with their pet still get a good night's rest
entry.summary: Researchers found that the sleep quality of the surprisingly high number of children who share a bed with their pets is indistinguishable from those who sleep alone.

entry.title: Kids who sleep with their pet still get a good night's rest
entry.summary: Researchers found that the sleep quality of the surprisingly high number of children who share a bed with their pets is indistinguishable from those who sleep alone.

entry.title: Gut to brain: Nerve cells detect what we eat
entry.summary: Nerve cells of the vagus nerve fulfill opposing tasks. The gut and the brain communicate with each other in order to adapt satiety and blood sugar levels during food consumption. The vagus nerve is an important communicator between these two organs. Researchers now took a closer look at the functions of the different nerve cells in the control center of the vagus nerve, and discovered something very surprising: although the nerve cells are located in the same control center, they innervate different regions of the gut and also differentially control satiety and blood sugar levels. This discovery could play an important role in the development of future therapeutic strategies against obesity and diabetes.

entry.title: General availability: Azure API Management Premium tier price reduction for incremental purchased units
entry.summary: After the first purchased unit, a price reduction of 50% will be applied on all subsequent units purchased.

entry.title: Healthy diet before, during pregnancy linked to lower complications
entry.summary: A healthy diet around the time of conception through the second trimester may reduce the risk of several common pregnancy complications, suggests a new study. Expectant women in the study who scored high on any of three measures of healthy eating had lower risks for gestational diabetes, pregnancy-related blood pressure disorders and preterm birth.

entry.title: 'Prescription' to sit less, move more advised for mildly high blood pressure and cholesterol
entry.summary: Physical activity is the optimal first treatment choice for adults with mild to moderately elevated blood pressure and blood cholesterol who otherwise have low heart disease risk. About 21% of adults in the US with mild to moderately raised blood pressure and 28-37% of those with mild to moderate elevated cholesterol levels may be best served by a prescription for lifestyle-only treatment, which includes increasing physical activity.

entry.title: People who eat a healthy diet including whole fruits may be less likely to develop diabetes
entry.summary: A new study finds people who consume two servings of fruit per day have 36% lower odds of developing type 2 diabetes than those who consume less than half a serving.

entry.title: Modulating rapamycin target protein promotes autophagy, lowering toxic Huntingtin protein
entry.summary: Recent failed clinical trials of a drug designed to clear the mutant Huntingtin protein that causes Huntington's disease (HD) heightens the need for new approaches for the devastating, incurable, progressive neurodegenerative genetic disorder. Scientists have found that the targeting the protein called FK506-binding protein 51 or FKBP51 promotes the clearing of those toxic proteins via autophagy, a natural process whereby cells recycle damaged proteins and mitochondria and use them for nutrition.

entry.title: Role of sleep-related brain activity in clearing toxic proteins and preventing Alzheimer's disease
entry.summary: Evidence of sleep-dependent low-frequency (less than 0.1 Hz) global brain activity in the clearance of Alzheimer's disease-related toxin buildup is presented in new research. This neuronal activity was more strongly linked with cerebrospinal fluid flow in healthy controls than higher risk groups and patients, and the findings could serve as a potential imaging marker for clinicians in evaluating patients.

entry.title: Role of sleep-related brain activity in clearing toxic proteins and preventing Alzheimer's disease
entry.summary: Evidence of sleep-dependent low-frequency (less than 0.1 Hz) global brain activity in the clearance of Alzheimer's disease-related toxin buildup is presented in new research. This neuronal activity was more strongly linked with cerebrospinal fluid flow in healthy controls than higher risk groups and patients, and the findings could serve as a potential imaging marker for clinicians in evaluating patients.

entry.title: Role of sleep-related brain activity in clearing toxic proteins and preventing Alzheimer's disease
entry.summary: Evidence of sleep-dependent low-frequency (less than 0.1 Hz) global brain activity in the clearance of Alzheimer's disease-related toxin buildup is presented in new research. This neuronal activity was more strongly linked with cerebrospinal fluid flow in healthy controls than higher risk groups and patients, and the findings could serve as a potential imaging marker for clinicians in evaluating patients.

entry.title: Healthy lifestyle linked to better cognition for oldest adults -- regardless of genetic risk
entry.summary: A new analysis of adults aged 80 years and older shows that a healthier lifestyle is associated with a lower risk of cognitive impairment, and that this link does not depend on whether a person carries a particular form of the gene APOE.

entry.title: Junk food game helps people eat less and lose weight
entry.summary: Using a brain-training app helps people eat less junk food and lose weight, new research suggests.

entry.title: It's never too early to begin healthy eating habits
entry.summary: Researchers found that when health workers were trained to promote infant healthy feeding practices to pregnant women their children consumed less fats and carbohydrates at 3 years of age and had lower measures of body fat at the age of 6. The study is the first to show that the roots for obesity start in the first year of life, after mothers stop breastfeeding.

entry.title: It's never too early to begin healthy eating habits
entry.summary: Researchers found that when health workers were trained to promote infant healthy feeding practices to pregnant women their children consumed less fats and carbohydrates at 3 years of age and had lower measures of body fat at the age of 6. The study is the first to show that the roots for obesity start in the first year of life, after mothers stop breastfeeding.

entry.title: Early bird or night owl? Study links shift worker sleep to 'chronotype'
entry.summary: Getting enough sleep can be a real challenge for shift workers affecting their overall health. But what role does being an early bird or night owl play in getting good rest? Researchers find a link between chronotype and amount of sleep shift workers can get with their irregular schedules.

entry.title: Early bird or night owl? Study links shift worker sleep to 'chronotype'
entry.summary: Getting enough sleep can be a real challenge for shift workers affecting their overall health. But what role does being an early bird or night owl play in getting good rest? Researchers find a link between chronotype and amount of sleep shift workers can get with their irregular schedules.

entry.title: React to any GitHub release to show your support!
entry.summary: React to any GitHub release to show your support!

entry.title: Overweight or obesity worsens liver-damaging effects of alcohol
entry.summary: The largest study of its kind has found people in the overweight or obese range who drink alcohol are at greater risk of liver disease and mortality.

entry.title: Researchers develop new measure of brain health
entry.summary: A new measure of brain health may offer a novel approach to identifying individuals at risk of memory and thinking problems, according to new research results.

entry.title: Free text search for code scanning alerts
entry.summary: Free text search for code scanning alerts

entry.title: Recently
entry.summary:
This was a big month. May 1 feels like eons ago. I’m in a different place (New York). The situation with COVID feels dramatically different. Acquired a few new gray hairs due to the absolute horror which is the logistics of moving cross-country, especially during a pandemic. We spent a few nervous weeks waiting for furniture to arrive, and dreading the next interaction with our absolutely-terrible-no-good moving company. When VCs and some tech company ‘disrupt’ moving by undercutting and technologizing movers, I will make an exception and cheer them on: this industry deserves to end. But then, seeing so many old faces, reconnecting, finding a new favorite restaurant and bar every few days. Visiting family. Feeling some optimism about the general future.
Caleb Porzio’s making 100k as an em…

entry.title: Diabetes remission diet also lowers blood pressure and reduces need for medication
entry.summary: New research published in Diabetologia has shown that if people achieve and maintain substantial weight loss to manage their type 2 diabetes, many can also effectively control their high blood pressure and stop or cut down on their anti-hypertensive medication.

entry.title: Tai chi can mirror healthy benefits of conventional exercise
entry.summary: A new study shows that tai chi mirrors the beneficial effects of conventional exercise by reducing waist circumference in middle-aged and older adults with central obesity.

entry.title: Declining biodiversity in wild Amazon fisheries threatens human diet
entry.summary: A new study of dozens of wild fish species commonly consumed in the Peruvian Amazon says that people there could suffer major nutritional shortages if ongoing losses in fish biodiversity continue. Furthermore, the increasing use of aquaculture and other substitutes may not compensate.

entry.title: Exoskeleton-assisted walking may improve bowel function in people with spinal cord injury
entry.summary: A team of researchers has shown that physical intervention plans that included exoskeleton-assisted walking helped people with spinal cord injury evacuate more efficiently and improved the consistency of their stool.

entry.title: Exoskeleton therapy improves mobility, cognition and brain connectivity in people with MS
entry.summary: A team of multiple sclerosis (MS) experts led a pilot randomized controlled trial of robotic-exoskeleton assisted exercise rehabilitation (REAER) effects on mobility, cognition, and brain connectivity in people with substantial MS-related disability. Their results showed that REAER is likely an effective intervention, and is a promising therapy for improving the lives of those with MS.

entry.title: Waking just one hour earlier cuts depression risk by double digits, study finds
entry.summary: A genetic study of 840,000 people found that shifting sleep time earlier by just an hour decreases risk of major depression by 23 percent.

entry.title: Waking just one hour earlier cuts depression risk by double digits, study finds
entry.summary: A genetic study of 840,000 people found that shifting sleep time earlier by just an hour decreases risk of major depression by 23 percent.

entry.title: Alzheimer's: Blood oxygen levels could explain why memory loss is an early symptom
entry.summary: Scientists have recorded blood oxygen levels in the hippocampus and provided experimental proof for why the area, commonly referred to as 'the brain's memory center', is vulnerable to damage and degeneration, a precursor to Alzheimer's disease.

entry.title: GitHub Sponsors adds Suggested Tiers to profile setup
entry.summary: GitHub Sponsors adds Suggested Tiers to profile setup

entry.title: Parasites as fountains of youth: Study finds infected ants live much longer
entry.summary: According to the results of a multi-year scientific study, ants of the species Temnothorax nylanderi show exceptionally high survival rates when infected with a tapeworm.

entry.title: Changes in how cholesterol breaks down in the body may accelerate progression of dementia
entry.summary: The blood-brain barrier is impermeable to cholesterol, yet high blood cholesterol is associated with increased risk of Alzheimer's disease and vascular dementia. However, the underlying mechanisms mediating this relationship are poorly understood. A new study suggests that disturbances in the conversion of cholesterol to bile acids may play a role in the development of dementia.

entry.title: Three years younger in just eight weeks? A new study suggests yes!
entry.summary: A groundbreaking clinical trial shows we can reduce biological age (as measured by the Horvath 2013 DNAmAge clock) by more than three years in only eight weeks with diet and lifestyle through balancing DNA methylation.

entry.title: Three years younger in just eight weeks? A new study suggests yes!
entry.summary: A groundbreaking clinical trial shows we can reduce biological age (as measured by the Horvath 2013 DNAmAge clock) by more than three years in only eight weeks with diet and lifestyle through balancing DNA methylation.

entry.title: Aging: Clinical trial on potential reversal of epigenetic age using a diet and lifestyle
entry.summary: A randomized controlled clinical trial was conducted among 43 healthy adult males between the ages of 50-72. The 8-week treatment program included diet, sleep, exercise and relaxation guidance, and supplemental probiotics and phytonutrients.

entry.title: Mathematical model developed to prevent botulism
entry.summary: Food producers can use a mathematical model to ensure their products do not cause botulism.

entry.title: New research may explain why some people derive more benefits from exercise than others
entry.summary: A new study published led by investigators at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center (BIDMC) provides insights related to mechanistic links between physical fitness and overall health and the reasons why the same exercise can have different effects in different people.

entry.title: Escape from oblivion: How the brain reboots after deep anesthesia
entry.summary: An innovative study uses the anesthetics propofol and isoflurane in humans to study the patterns of reemerging consciousness and cognitive function after anesthesia.

entry.title: Amazon indigenous group's lifestyle may hold a key to slowing down aging
entry.summary: The Tsimane indigenous people of the Bolivian Amazon experience less brain atrophy than their American and European peers. The decrease in their brain volumes with age is 70% slower than in Western populations.

entry.title: PowerShell support in Durable Functions is now generally available
entry.summary: PowerShell users can use Durable Functions create serverless workflows to orchestrate complex, long-running automation processes.

entry.title: Public preview: Introducing new Durable Functions storage provider options
entry.summary: Durable Functions, an extension to the Azure Functions runtime, adds two new storage provider options in public preview.

entry.title: Don't count on caffeine to fight sleep deprivation
entry.summary: Sleep scientists assessed how effective caffeine was in counteracting the negative effects of sleep deprivation on cognition.

entry.title: Non-parents expand 'facial dexterity' in caring for infants among primates
entry.summary: Non-parents expand the range of their facial expressions in caring for infants among primates. The study shows the ability, among non-relatives, to both decipher facial expressions and to be attuned to others' emotional states, revealing the evolutionary nature of communication.

entry.title: Proteomics reveals how exercise increases the efficiency of muscle energy production
entry.summary: By applying mass spectrometry, scientists provide some of the most detailed data on how mitochondrial proteins cluster into supercomplexes - a process that makes mitochondria more efficient at producing energy.

entry.title: GitHub Desktop 2.8.2 includes native builds for Apple silicon
entry.summary: GitHub Desktop 2.8.2 includes native builds for Apple silicon

entry.title: Deciphering structure of a toxic matter that destroys the nerves in the brain
entry.summary: Researchers reveal the structure of a hetero-oligomer nano-aggregate - a substance that causes Parkinson's and dementia - through quadruple force mapping.

entry.title: New tools to discover and resolve pull request conversations (beta)
entry.summary: New tools to discover and resolve pull request conversations (beta)

entry.title: Public preview: Native support for WebSocket APIs in Azure API Management
entry.summary: Azure API Management announces native support for WebSocket APIs.

entry.title: General availability: Logic Apps with new hosting options
entry.summary: Logic Apps has been updated with new hosting options, improved performance, and developer workflows.

entry.title: New filtering and metadata experience on GitHub Mobile
entry.summary: New filtering and metadata experience on GitHub Mobile

entry.title: How to boost muscle regeneration and rebuild tissue
entry.summary: In work that could one day help athletes as well as aging adults regenerate tissue more effectively, scientists increased the regeneration of muscle cells in mice by activating the precursors of muscle cells.

entry.title: 'Rejuvenating' the Alzheimer's brain
entry.summary: Alzheimer's disease is the main cause of dementia and current therapeutic strategies cannot prevent, slow down or cure the pathology. The disease is characterized by memory loss, caused by the degeneration and death of neuronal cells in several regions of the brain, including the hippocampus. Researchers have identified a small molecule that can be used to rejuvenate the brain and counteract the memory loss.

entry.title: Tutorials, guides, and documentation updates for Codespaces
entry.summary: Tutorials, guides, and documentation updates for Codespaces

entry.title: Low blood flow in the brain may be an early sign of Parkinson's disease
entry.summary: Patients who suffer from REM sleep behavior disorder have altered blood flow in the brain, which can lead to a lack of oxygen in the brain tissue. In the long term, this may cause symptoms of Parkinson's disease.

entry.title: Low blood flow in the brain may be an early sign of Parkinson's disease
entry.summary: Patients who suffer from REM sleep behavior disorder have altered blood flow in the brain, which can lead to a lack of oxygen in the brain tissue. In the long term, this may cause symptoms of Parkinson's disease.

entry.title: Press (re)play to remember - How the brain strengthens memories during sleep
entry.summary: While we sleep, the brain produces particular activation patterns. When two of these patterns - slow oscillations and sleep spindles - gear into each other, previous experiences are reactivated. The stronger the reactivation, the clearer will be our recall of past events, a new study reveals.

entry.title: Fat around the heart linked to increased risk of heart failure
entry.summary: Study shows risk doubles in women and goes up by 50 percent in men.

entry.title: Full-genome CRISPR screen reveals surprising ways neurons survive oxidative stress
entry.summary: When a single gene in a cell is turned on or off, its resulting presence or absence can affect the function and survival of the cell. Researchers have now successfully catalogued this effect in the human neuron by separately toggling each of the 20,000 genes in the human genome.

entry.title: How tendons become stiffer and stronger
entry.summary: Researchers deciphered the cellular mechanisms through which tendons can adapt to mechanical stresses. People who carry a certain variant of a gene that is key to this mechanism show improved jumping performance.

entry.title: Bile acids trigger satiety in the brain
entry.summary: Scientists have discovered a new role for bile acids: they curb appetite by entering the brain. Their findings provide new insights into the signals and mechanisms by which satiety is controlled and may have implications for treating obesity.

entry.title: Game on: Game-based program boosts physical activity among diabetes patients
entry.summary: Researchers showed that adding gamification with either competition or support increased physical activity for patients with Type 2 diabetes.

entry.title: Simple diagnostic tool predicts individual risk of Alzheimer's
entry.summary: Researchers at Lund University in Sweden have developed an algorithm that combines data from a simple blood test and brief memory tests, to predict with great accuracy who will develop Alzheimer's disease in the future. The findings are published in Nature Medicine.

entry.title: Move of official IRC channels to libera.chat
entry.summary: As some of you may have read over the past days, there has been an ownership dispute over the freenode.net network. The IRC network has been used by Arch Linux and many other projects over the past decades as a platform for discussion and support. The dispute led to the exodus of most former freenode staff from the network and the founding of a new network: libera.chat Starting today, Arch Linux and its sister projects Arch Linux ARM and Arch Linux 32 will begin migrating the official IRC channels from freenode.net to libera.chat. Please bear with us as this can take some time to be fully settled in. We thank the freenode community for the many years of great service and collaboration.

entry.title: Study finds women with osteoporosis and low bone density are at increased risk of hearing loss
entry.summary: Researchers found that risk of subsequent moderate or worse hearing loss was up to 40 percent higher in study participants with osteoporosis or LBD.

entry.title: Researchers discover oligodendrocyte loss and subtype alteration in CTE brains
entry.summary: While many of the scientific studies to date have focused on repetitive head trauma leading to the development of abnormal tau, a new study provides insights into white matter changes that may offer new targets for therapies.

entry.title: Telomere length, a longevity measure, may be determined early in life
entry.summary: One of the first studies to examine telomere length (TL) in childhood finds that the initial setting of TL during prenatal development and in the first years of life may determine one's TL throughout childhood and potentially even into adulthood or older age. The study also finds that TL decreases most rapidly from birth to age 3, followed by a period of maintenance into the pre-puberty period, although it was sometimes seen to lengthen.

entry.title: No link between milk and increased cholesterol according to new study of 2 million people
entry.summary: Regular consumption of milk is not associated with increased levels of cholesterol, according to new research of nearly 2 million people.

entry.title: Myopia link to poor sleep, and screen time
entry.summary: New research from Australia indicates people with myopia are more likely to experience poorer sleep quality than people with normal vision. The study indicates that people with short-sightedness have more delayed circadian rhythms and lower production of melatonin, a hormone secreted in the brain and responsible for regulating sleep at night, compared to people with normal vision.

entry.title: Myopia link to poor sleep, and screen time
entry.summary: New research from Australia indicates people with myopia are more likely to experience poorer sleep quality than people with normal vision. The study indicates that people with short-sightedness have more delayed circadian rhythms and lower production of melatonin, a hormone secreted in the brain and responsible for regulating sleep at night, compared to people with normal vision.

entry.title: Explanatiion of how religious beliefs may be formed
entry.summary: Feeling anxious can direct our attention and memory toward supernatural beings such as gods, a new study has found.

entry.title: Cancer treatments may accelerate cellular aging
entry.summary: New research indicates that certain anti-cancer therapies may hasten cellular aging, where changes in the DNA of patients may contribute to greater inflammation and fatigue.
